title-group.article-title: Pathogenic Mechanisms Linking Periodontal Diseases With Adverse Pregnancy Outcomes

article-meta.aff: 1Unit of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Department of Clinical Sciences L. Sacco, and Center for Fetal Research Giorgio Pardi, University of Milan, Milan, Italy
2Dental Clinic, Department of Medicine, Surgery and Dentistry, University of Milano and WHO Collaborating Centre of Milan for Epidemiology and Community Dentistry, Milano, Italy
3Preventive and Community Dentistry, Department of Oral Sciences, University of Rome “La Sapienza”, Roma, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Irene Cetin, Ostetricia e Ginecologia, Ospedale Luigi Sacco, Via G.B. Grassi 74, 20157 Milano, Italy Email: irene.cetin@unimi.it

abstract.p: In the last 2 decades, a large proportion of studies have focused on the relationship between maternal periodontal disease and poor obstetric outcomes. The aim of the present review is to summarize the current knowledge about human studies on the pathogenetic mechanisms linking periodontal diseases with adverse pregnancy outcomes. A search of the medical literature was conducted using NIH (National Institute of Health) Pubmed through April 2011. Articles were identified with the Medical Subject Heading (MeSH) and free text terms “small for gestational age (SGA),” “preeclampsia,” “preterm labor,” and “periodontal disease.” Experimental human studies have shown that periodontal pathogens may disseminate toward placental and fetal tissues accompanied by an increase in inflammatory mediators in the placenta. As such, new inflammatory reactions within the placental tissues of the pregnant woman may occur, the physiological levels of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) and tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) in the amniotic fluid may increase and eventually lead to premature delivery. Although many data from clinical trials suggest that periodontal disease may increase the adverse pregnancy outcome, the exact pathogenetic mechanism involved remains controversial. The findings explain the potential link between periodontal infections and adverse pregnancy outcomes. First, periodontal bacteria can directly cause infections both of the uteroplacenta and the fetus; second, systemic inflammatory changes induced by periodontal diseases can activate responses at the maternal–fetal interface. Of note, associative studies have produced different results in different population groups and no conclusive evidence has still been produced for the potential role of preventive periodontal care to reduce the risk factors of preterm birth.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pregnancy complications, such as preeclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and preterm birth (PTB), represent one of the major unsolved public health problems because of their prevalence associated with high neonatal and maternal mortality, long-term pediatric disability, and consequences in adulthood.

Recent studies have implicated a variety of infections, including periodontal diseases, as risk factors for adverse pregnancy outcomes such as prematurity and low birth weight (LBW). The development of a proinflammatory maternal status has recently been addressed for its key role in the physiopathological pathway of obstetrical complications. 1 In particular, uterine infections may account for 25% to 40% of PTBs, and they are strongly linked with a proinflammatory systemic status. 2,3 Infections at the fetomaternal interface are known to upregulate the production of local proinflammatory cytokines, metalloproteinases, and prostaglandins leading to membrane weakening, early rupture of membranes, and uterine contractions.

In this context, the oral cavity has been proposed as a source of hematogenous transmission of pathogens that affect normal pregnancy development. Periodontal diseases (gingivitis and periodontitis) are among the most common chronic infections, affecting up to 50% of humans and have been found to be an independent putative risk factor for pregnancy-related complications such as PTBs. 4 Periodontitis may represent a distant source of low-grade systemic inflammation in the mother, having therefore an indirect effect also on the placenta and the fetus or it may act through the direct translocation of periodontal pathogens.

Recent evidence suggests that periodontitis might have systemic consequences through the direct translocation of bacteria and/or bacterial substances and/or the local or distant increase of host inflammatory mediators and cytokines like C-reactive protein (CRP), prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), matrix metalloproteinases, interleukin 1 (IL-1), IL-6, and tumor necrosis factor α (TNF-α). 5 Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are pattern recognition receptors that play a key role in pregnancy maintenance, placental immune protection, and delivery initiation. Recently, abnormalities in decidual TLRs expression or function have been linked with preterm delivery and particularly to periodontal pathogens placental infection. 6,7
This review summarizes the current knowledge about human studies in this field. In some cases, animal studies are also included in relation to specific pathogenetic mechanisms.

sec.title: Oral Biofilms and Infection of the Maternal–Fetal Interface
sec.p: Prematurity and LBW are strictly linked with the presence of infections in different organs such as the urinary and respiratory tracts. It has been noted that more than 40% of PTBs occur in women with an intrauterine infection, and this association seems to be more marked as the prematurity increases. 8 A consistent observation proving an association between subclinical infections and PTB is the evidence of a greater prevalence of histological chorioamnionitis in preterm than in full-term birth. 1 Most cases of histological chorioamnionitis are due to infections and they are histologically characterized by the infiltration of polymorphonucleocyte cells in the membranes. Moreover, the percentage of histological chorioamnionitis has been reported as less than 20% in newborns weighing over 3000 g, and over 60% for those weighing less than 1500 g. Besides this, a considerable amount of epidemiological, clinical, and laboratory information suggests that urinary tract infections may cause PTBs. 1

With these premises, in recent years many studies have investigated the potential role of oral cavity infections in causing pathologies during pregnancy. 9 –11 Periodontal disease is a common infection affecting more than 23% of women between 30 and 54 years. 12 In the absence of adequate oral hygiene, periodontal bacteria accumulate in the gingival crevice and form an organized structure called “bacterial biofilm.” In mature biofilms, bacteria possess a large quantity of virulent factors such as lipopolysaccarides (LPSs) which cause direct destruction of periodontal tissue or stimulate the host to a local inflammatory response which, though intended to eliminate the infection, may cause a subsequent loss of periodontal structures. Furthermore, bacteria and their virulence products can enter the blood stream, disseminate throughout the body, and trigger the induction of a systemic inflammatory response or ectopic infections.

The ability of periodontal pathogens and their virulence factors to spread and induce both systemic and local inflammatory response has lead to the hypothesis that the periodontal diseases might have consequences going beyond the periodontal tissues themselves. This concept was introduced by Miller already in 1891, when he published the “theory of focal infection.” 13 Based on this theory, oral foci of infection were considered responsible for a number of systemic or local diseases like tonsillitis, pneumonia, endocarditis, and septicemia. In more recent years, Collins and colleagues 14 hypothesized that oral cavity infections, like periodontitis, might be a source of bacteria and inflammatory mediators which could disseminate in the human body through the blood circulation to reach the fetal placental unit and induce pregnancy complications.

In fact, important periodontal pathogens have been detected in placentas of women with preeclampsia 15 and in the amniotic fluid of pregnant women with a diagnosis of premature labor 16 or premature labor with intact membranes. 17,18

Offenbacher et al 19 were the first to report a link in humans between poor maternal periodontal health and composite adverse pregnancy outcome of preterm and LBW (PLBW). They reported that women with periodontal disease were much more likely than periodontally healthy women to experience PLBW infants.

A direct demonstration came from the study by Collins et al. 14 This study demonstrated that Porphyromonas gingivalis injected in pregnant hamsters leads to a greater risk of delivering low-weight hamsters (weighing 20% less than normal) together with an increase in inflammatory mediators (TNF-α and PGE2) at the site of infection and in the amniotic fluid. This was the first proof of a possible association between periodontal disease and adverse outcomes in pregnancy.

In 2001, Mitchell-Lewis et al 20 examined the composition of the subgingival plaque in a preterm LBW group compared to the control groups of full-term births. They removed 4 subgingival plaque samples (1 on each first molar) from 145 out of 164 study participants and analyzed them, focusing on 12 bacterial species (Campylobacter rectus, Peptostreptococcus micros, Eubacterium nodatum, Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans, P gingivalis, Prevotella intermedia, Prevotella nigrescens, Streptococcus intermedius, Eikenella corrodens, Fusobacterium nucleatum, Bacteroides forsythus, and Treponema denticola). Though no significant differences were found in periodontal parameters between premature and full-term birth participants, the two groups differed in their subgingival plaque composition. The ones of PTB showed higher levels of the species B forsythus and C rectus and greater levels of P nigrescens, E corrodens, and E nodatum.

Interestingly, several studies show that many cases with clinical evidence for chorioamnionitis are not associated with infections in the urogenital tract and have negative chorioamnionic cultures. Indeed, in the histological analysis of the inflamed chorioamniotic membrane, no bacterial organisms are found in 18% to 49% of the cases. 21 For this reason, it has been speculated that participants with periodontal disease could have transitory bacteremia which, on reaching the placenta, could induce an inflammatory response and bring on birth. However, most of the bacterial species associated with periodontal infection are anaerobes and would confront unfavorable conditions on entering the blood stream and infecting the fetal placental unit. 22

Madianos et al 4 studied the relations between maternal periodontal disease and adverse birth outcomes, examining 15 species or the red and orange clusters (Table 1), maternal immunoglobulin G (IgG), and fetal IgM (as index of exposure to these microorganisms). The purpose of the study was to evaluate whether periodontal infection leads to the diffusion of periodontal microorganisms; and whether these bacteria on reaching the fetal–placental unit would induce a maternal and/or fetal response leading to premature birth. Authors did not highlight important differences in the prevalence of pathogens of the subgingival plaque, although red cluster organisms were less frequent than orange cluster ones and present only in association to the latter.

caption.p: The List of Bacteria of Orange Complex and Red Complex

sec.p: However, maternal seropositivity (IgG) was greater for orange cluster organisms than for red cluster ones. Moreover, fetal seropositivity (IgM) to maternal periodontal pathogens was higher among preterm births than full-term ones. In particular, finding fetal IgM against C rectus and P intermedia was significantly more frequent in preterm births. Therefore, maternal periodontal pathogens seem to be able to present an antigenic challenge to the fetus, and this occurs more frequently in pregnancies associated with preterm birth. A further observation of this study was that the fetal seropositivity model of the red and orange clusters was opposite to that seen in maternal serum. Fetal exposure to red cluster microorganisms, followed by the orange cluster, seems therefore to be associated with premature birth. Thus, the maternal antibody response is protective from fetal exposure to these microorganisms.

Another study 23 investigated 12 bacterial species from 2 samples of subgingival plaque from a molar and foretooth element identifying periodontal indexes and creating an anamnestic collection in a control group (128 women with term delivery) and in a case group (53 women with preterm delivery). The results indicate that A actinomycetemcomitans and P nigrescens were associated with a reduction in the risk of premature delivery. On the other hand, C rectus and P micros increased the risk. Finally, no difference was found for the other bacterial species studied.

Since numerous studies have separately linked both periodontal disease and bacterial vaginosis with adverse pregnancy outcomes, 19,21,24
–27 a potential association between periodontal disease and bacterial vaginosis has recently been investigated. 28 In a large cohort of nonpregnant women in the United States, a small but significant association has indeed been reported between periodontal disease and bacterial vaginosis together with a possible trend between sexual behaviors and periodontal disease. The microbiological similarities between the oral and vaginal environments in the presence of periodontal disease and bacterial vaginosis, respectively, may indeed support a common pathophysiology, such as a deficient host response to infection. 29,30

sec.title: Oral Biofilms and Systemic Inflammation
sec.p: Periodontal microorganisms possess characteristics enabling them to act as pathogens not only in the oral cavity but also at a distance in other body areas. These characteristics include (1) the ability to colonize, (2) the ability to elude the host’s defence mechanisms, and (3) the ability to produce substances leading directly to tissue destruction. Periodontitis is indeed the destructive disease of the dental supporting tissues and its ethiopathogenic mechanisms result from the host response to the bacterial infection of the teeth and subgingival environment.

A actinomycetemcomitans and P gingivalis are the most studied periodontal pathogens. These 2 bacteria can invade tissues by penetrating through epithelial cells and interacting with the host organism’s defence system by a number of mechanisms. 31,32 At first, the neutrophil granulocytes form a barrier at the plaque–tissue interface controlling the number of bacteria and keeping them or their tissue surface products out. At the same time, the immune system produces antibodies which opsonize the bacteria. These antibodies allow neutrophils to recognize, ingest, and destroy the bacteria. Thus, these antibodies create a local response represented by gingival crevicular fluid, a modified inflammatory exudate which runs through the sulcular epithelium into the gingival pocket.

Some bacteria like A actinomycetemcomitans or C rectus produce leucotoxins which can kill the neutrophil organisms directly, thus weakening defences in the gingival crevice. 31 Other microorganisms like P gingivalis produce proteolytic enzymes which reduce the antibodies and complementary proteins directly or block the accumulation of these molecules on the bacterial surface. 5 This in turn blocks the accumulation of chemotactic complement derivatives which usually recruit further neutrophil organisms in the infection site.

Finally, some bacteria can invade tissue cells and block contact with neutrophil organisms and with the immune system molecules, thus starting a process of tissue destruction. Among these, bacteria localized at a periodontal level have systemic effects for the inflammatory response they trigger not only in the oral cavity but also in other body districts including the fetal–placental unit. In fact, they attract polymorphonucleates which, during the phagocytosis process, can release enzymes able to degrade the surrounding tissue, in particular collagen and the constituents of basal membranes, thus causing initial tissue damage.

Bacterial LPSs stimulate the production of inflammatory cytokines and inflammation mediators, including arachidonic acid and metabolites like PGE2. 5 The latter promote the release of derivative tissue enzymes and of matrix metalloproteinases which can further destroy the surrounding tissues and extracellular matrix.

The most common cytokines and inflammatory mediators involved in this process are IL-1, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α, and PGE2. 5 Interleukin 1 is a proinflammatory cytokines which promotes the entry of inflammatory cells into the infection site and stimulates the release of eicosanoids. Interleukin 6 stimulates the proliferation of plasma cells, thus secondary antibody production. High levels of IL-6 are found in inflamed tissues. Interleukin 8 possesses chemotactic attraction abilities, while PGE2 is a vasoactive eicosanoid produced by monocytes and fibroblasts. 5

Host susceptibility also plays an important role in determining the effects of infection. Recent studies indicate that polymorphisms of genes coding for IL-1 are associated with the severity of the periodontitis. 33,34 These polymorphisms are variations of the DNA sequence of genes codifying for IL-1α and IL-1β.

In conclusion, the systemic effects of periodontal disease need a predisposing periodontium vascular tissue that leads to inhibitory effects on antibody levels and on antibody response to bacterial plaque and to the production of proinflammatory mediators.

sec.title: Systemic Inflammation and Adverse Pregnancy Outcome
sec.p: Pregnancy represents an inflammatory challenge for the mother and the conceptus. The interplay at the fetal–maternal interface involves immunological interactions that allow blastocyst attachment to the uterine epithelium, syncytiotrophoblast erosion of maternal tissues, and extravillous trophoblast cells invasion of maternal spiral arteries. Inadequacies of these processes are associated with abortion, placental insufficiency, and later development of pregnancy pathologies such as preeclampsia, IUGR, and preterm delivery.

Systemic inflammation has been advocated as having a significant role in the pathogenesis of most pregnancy-related pathologies, such as preterm delivery and preeclampsia. The pathogenesis of PTB is thought to be multifactorial, possibly initiated by multiple mechanisms including infection, uteroplacental ischemia, hemorrhage, stress, and other immunologically mediated processes 35 ; however, the development of a proinflammatory condition is a common effect or pathway that centralizes all multiple risk factors. 36

Infections at the fetomaternal interface are known to upregulate the production of local proinflammatory cytokines, metalloproteinases, and prostaglandins that lead to membrane weakening, early membrane rupture, and uterine contraction initiation. 37 Periodontitis might represent one distant source of low-grade systemic inflammation in the mother, having therefore a direct effect on the mother, the placenta, and the fetus.

Periodontitis has a chronic inflammatory infection nature and acts as a reservoir of anaerobic gram-negative microorganisms, LPSs, and cytokines including PGE2 and TNF-α. Therefore, it can be considered a threat to the fetoplacental unit.

Gibbs et al 38 reported that an infection distant from the uteroplacental complex could represent an important risk factor for adverse pregnancy outcomes due to the transfer of some bacterial products, in particular inflammatory mediators (IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α, and PGE2) and endotoxins (LPS). Since then, the link between periodontal infection and preterm delivery has been one of the frontiers in dental research.

Proinflammatory cytokines, such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α, may activate the mechanisms of labor through placental and chorion–amnion production of PGE2. 39 Furthermore, these mediators can cross fetal membranes; so, it is possible that high levels of these cytokines synthesized at the level of periodontal infection could interfere with fetoplacental functions and contribute to the onset of preterm labor. 40,41 Increased levels of intraamniotic cytokines have indeed been reported in pregnancies complicated by preterm delivery. 42 In addition, some bacterial products such as LPS, present at the level of amniotic fluid in women with chorioamnionitis, can increase the amnios, chorion, and decidual production of interleukins. 43 The increase in these mediators can be associated with PLBW.

Dortbudak et al 24 postulated that periodontitis can cause preterm delivery through 2 different mechanisms. First, periodontitis can cause high levels of cytokines at the level of the gingival pouch, and throughout the maternal blood they can reach the amniotic fluid. Second, LPS secreted by periodontal pathogens can stimulate directly the placenta to produce TNF-α and IL-1. They reported a 20-fold higher risk of having a PTB in the presence of periodontitis. In this study, more red and orange cluster pathogens were found in subgingival plaque samples of the preterm group, and this was also associated with increased levels of IL-6 and PGE2 in the amniotic fluid. Besides, higher levels of IL-6 and PGE2 were found in patients with periodontitis than in those with healthy periodontium. Furthermore, a positive association between amniotic fluid levels of IL-6 and PGE2 and colony-forming units subgingival plaque samples was found.

Offenbacher et al 44 analyzed the relationship between PGE2 level in the gingival crevicular fluid and delivery outcomes. Several periodontal pathogens (B forsythus, P gingivalis, T denticola, and A actinomycetemcomitans) as well as PGE2 were found to be present in higher levels in women with preterm delivery. Moreover, an inverse association was found between birth weight, gestational age, and PGE2 gingival crevicular levels, suggesting a dose–effect relationship between PGE2 and preterm delivery. It has been speculated that an increase in PGE2 levels in the gingival crevicular fluid could be considered as a marker of periodontitis in active phase and LBW.

Recently, TLRs have been implicated in the pathogenesis of preterm labor. Toll-like receptors are transmembrane proteins that have an extracellular domain which gives each receptor a ligand specificity. So, while individually TLRs respond to limited ligands, collectively the family of TLRs can respond to a wide range of proteins associated with bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites. Stimulation of TLRs causes an immediate defensive response, including the production of an array of antimicrobial peptides and cytokines. Although extracellularly each TLR is distinct in its specificity, all receptors signal though a common pathway: the binding of the microbial molecule to the TLR sends a signal through the cytoplasm to the cell nucleus, activating genes coding for the synthesis and secretion of cytokines. 45

Expression of TLRs has been described in the human placenta, mostly in the trophoblast. 46 –48 Trophoblast cells coordinate the immune response during endometrial implantation and placental development 49 by regulating the migration of immune cells (macrophages and natural killer cells) to the endometrial implantation site through the activation of TLRs and production of chemokines. 46,50,51 Abnormalities in decidual TLRs expression or function have been linked with abnormal placentation, inflammation, and adverse pregnancy outcomes 7 Toll-like receptor 4 is selectively activated by gram-negative LPS, in conjunction with CD14. 52 Recently, a combined oral infection with C rectus and C rectus/P gingivalis, 2 gram-negative periodontal pathogens has been found to induce placental inflammation along with enhanced expression of TLR4 in a pregnant murine model. 6
Therefore, data from animal and human experimental studies point to a causal relationship between periodontal bacteria and pathologic responses at the maternal–fetal interface.

sec.title: Associative Studies: Why They Tell Different Stories?
sec.p: Evidence coming from epidemiological studies has also mainly supported a positive association between periodontitis and adverse pregnancy outcomes, but this has not been consistent. Several human case–control observational or interventional studies have indeed confirmed a link between presence, severity, and progression of periodontitis and adverse outcomes of pregnancy such as preeclampsia, premature rupture of the membranes, or birth of preterm, and LBW babies. However, other studies have failed to find such a link, leading to an important debate among researchers. 53 Many concerns come from the population selection criteria, periodontal disease, and pregnancy outcome definitions and also therapy advises.

In 2006, Xiong 54 analyzed the results of 25 studies. Most of them 19,55
–58 have reported a positive association between periodontal disease and increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes. Nevertheless, the authors have noticed several potential biases among these studies. First, there was a great variation in periodontal disease definitions. 58 –60 Additionally, differences have been found in population selection criteria. Furthermore, some studies had an insufficient sample size. 24,55,59,61
–64

Interestingly, studies conducted in the United States or in developing countries (including African American women and women from low economic social level) have reported a strong evidence of an association between periodontal disease and adverse pregnancy outcomes. 20,56,63 On the contrary, the studies conducted in European countries and Canada which offer their citizens universal health care, and with very good oral hygiene habits, have not found evidence of an association, 23,61,65
–68 except for a recent study showing an increased risk of premature delivery in association with periodontal disease in a selected Italian population with high socioeconomic status. 69 Another problem is the considerable variation in definitions of adverse pregnancy outcomes. Many studies have used “preterm low birth weight”’—meaning LBW (<2500 g) infants born preterm (<37 weeks). Other studies have used such labels as “preterm OR low birthweight” and “preterm AND/OR low birthweight.” However, PTBs and LBW infant have distinct etiologies; therefore, such definitions are somewhat confusing—in some situations apparently excluding preterm infants with normal birth weight or full-term infants with LBW (ie, IUGR). Both scenarios are considered clinically important and possibly associated with periodontal disease.

Similar conclusions were reached by a recent meta-analysis of 17 articles. 11 A statistically significant association was reported between periodontitis and adverse pregnancy outcomes. Again, the heterogeneity among the studies was considerable and statistically significant. The authors suggested that the possible source of heterogeneity was represented by not taking into account ethnicity or socioeconomic status as confounding factors. Moreover, there were differences in the definitions of both periodontal disease and adverse pregnancy outcome among the studies considered. Several criteria have been used to define periodontitis and often in association with each other. Some authors have taken into account probing depth (PD), clinical attachment loss (CAL), and bleeding on probing (BOP). 19,26 Plaque index has been added by Moore et al, 59 while Jeffcoat et al 70 have considered only PD and CAL. Furthermore, in other studies additional parameters have been used: microbiologic analysis (M), 24,66,67 dental mobility, 59 calculus index, 58,57 serum cytokine levels, 66 –68 gingival crevicular fluid cytokine levels, 67,68 and generating even more heterogeneity.

Once again the majority of the studies have considered “preterm low birth weight,” “preterm OR low birth weight,” and “preterm AND/OR low birth weight” as pregnancy outcomes, not considering possibly different pathophysiology and different severity of the disease in the groups.

Other studies have used alternative definitions of outcomes such as late miscarriage, preterm contractions, threatened preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, and spontaneous abortion without a precise definition of the disease, therefore generating more confusion. In particular, IUGR has been often generically defined by a birth weight less than 10 percentile, thus identifying small for gestational age and not IUGR.

The EPIPAP study (EPIdemiological study on the relation between Periodontitis and Adverse Pregnancy outcomes) conducted in a group of French postpartum women evaluated the impact of periodontitis definition on the frequency of the periodontal disease and on the association with known risk factors for periodontitis. 69 A total of 932 term postpartum women were examined using 6 different, widely accepted, definitions of periodontal disease, using single or combined criteria as follows: (1) CAL ≥3 mm, (2) PD ≥4 mm, (3) CAL ≥3 mm and PD ≥4 mm at the same site, (4) CAL ≥4 mm or PD ≥5 mm, (5) PD ≥4 mm and CAL ≥3 and BOP at the same site, and (6) at least 4 teeth with a PD of ≥4 mm and CAL of ≥3 mm at the same site. The relationships between each definition and maternal characteristics (age, educational level, smoking habits, and time since last dental visit) were analyzed. This study confirmed that the definition of periodontitis changes the frequency of the disease from 12.1% to 37.7% (higher values with single criteria and lower values with combined criteria) with different odd ratios for the maternal risk factors for periodontitis. Once again this finding underlines the impact of the definition of periodontitis on the associative studies linking periodontal disease with adverse pregnancy outcomes.

sec.title: Dental Intervention: Is It Useful?
sec.p: In the last decade, many studies have investigated whether the treatment of periodontitis with scaling and root planing could have an effective role in reducing the incidence of PTB and/or LBW. Contrasting findings have emerged and some authors have concluded that there is no sufficient evidence to provide periodontal screening and periodontal treatment for pregnant women to reduce the risk for PTB and/or LBW. 53,71 –73 Intervention studies that included small-scale, single-center studies have reported improvement in pregnancy outcomes following periodontal treatment; on the contrary, large-scale multicenter studies have not confirmed that efficacy.

The MOTOR (for Maternal Oral Therapy to Reduce Obstetric Risk) study enrolled a large number of patients (n = 1760) from different US states (Alabama, North Carolina, and Texas), with 882 patients receiving scaling and root planing treatment during the second trimester and 878 receiving periodontal care after delivery. 74 No differences between the 2 groups were reported for PTB, birth weight, Apgar score, and admission to neonatal intensive care unit. However, periodontal health was not restored by the treatment provided, as reflected in the high PDs and bleeding scores at delivery. The Periodontal Infection and Prematurity Study (PIPS) multicenter randomized trial enrolling more than 300 patients in each group (treatment vs control group) also failed to identify a positive effect of the treatment in reducing the rate of spontaneous preterm delivery. On the contrary, evidence coming from other studies 75 have shown that pregnant women who received periodontal treatment before delivery had better pregnancy outcomes than did those individuals who received no treatment.

It seems that trials involving a single patient enrollment site and a defined subpopulation tend to produce results with a positive effect of periodontal treatment, 63,76,77 whereas trials involving multiple centers and a large general population fail to demonstrate efficacy. 74,78,79 It has been hypothesized that periodontal health may affect the birth outcome in a subpopulation rather than in the general population, or enrolling patients at multiple sites makes it more challenging to manage and produce consistent results. Inconsistent results from different sites have indeed been reported in multicenter studies.

However, potential methodological weaknesses could have potentially determined these contradictory results. Different study designs, different periodontal disease diagnostic criteria, and disparate periodontal therapies have been reported. Probing depth alone is not sufficient to distinguish between gingivitis and periodontitis. Furthermore, the use of attachment loss as a single measure for periodontal disease definition can result in treating women without current periodontitis. Moreover, some studies have considered gingivitis in the same group of periodontitis.

Therefore, inconsistencies may be due to differences in patient population selection, as well as in the practical management of patient care. Treatment of less severe diseases, such as pregnancy-associated gingivitis or initial localized chronic periodontitis, tends to be effective in improving birth outcome. 76,77 Indeed, less severe periodontitis is easier to reverse and improve with the current therapy of scaling and root planing.

The type and the number of patient care could also interfere with the results. Single treatment of scaling and root planing during the second trimester did not produce significant results; on the contrary, multiple treatments throughout pregnancy have been associated with consistent periodontal health condition improvements. 74,77,79 It has been well documented that the gingival conditions deteriorate throughout pregnancy and improve after delivery. 80 Thus, early treatment does not preclude the periodontal conditions from worsening later in pregnancy. Similarly, a single treatment during the second trimester may not be sufficient to prevent gingival inflammation later in pregnancy.
In addition, some studies are biased for confounder factors such as multiparity, history of previous PTB, and genitourinary infections, and they should be interpreted very carefully.

A recent metaanalysis 71 conducted on randomized clinical control studies evaluated the effect of periodontal therapy on PLBW. The review included only studies with the same definition of periodontitis (clinical attachment level and probing pocket depth) and studies have been controlled for confounders such as multiparity, previous PTB, and genitourinary infections. All patients in the intervention group received instruction for dental plaque control, supragingival scaling, and root planing. In this study, periodontal treatment was not statistically associated with a reduction in PTB and LBW incidence and the authors concluded that there is no evidence of a protective effect of periodontal therapy in reducing PTB and LBW.

However, it has been recently hypothesized that pregnancy may not be an appropriate period for periodontal intervention since treatment could be performed too late to reduce inflammation and it could potentially lead to an increase in bacteremia. Therefore, treatment in the prepregnancy period could be more effective in reducing adverse pregnancy outcomes, but this hypothesis needs to be tested in randomized clinical trials. 81
Therefore, the question as to whether the treatment of periodontal disease should be recommended to pregnant woman aiming to reduce pregnancy complications is still open.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A potential link between periodontal infections and adverse pregnancy outcomes has been established based on 2 principles. First, periodontal bacteria can directly cause infections to the uteroplacenta and to the fetus; second, systemic inflammatory changes induced by periodontal diseases can activate responses at the maternal–fetal interface. However, associative studies have produced different results in different population groups and no conclusive evidence has still been produced for the potential role of preventive periodontal care to reduce the risk factors of PTB.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: the Italian COFIN --PRIN 2005 “Association between periodontitis and adverse pregnancy outcome, a multidisciplinary approach” and by the Italian COFIN-PRIN Grant 2008 “Clinical and biochemical markers for inflammation and oxidative stress in pregnant women with premature delivery”.
